Title:
Clustering of two genes involved in cyanate detoxification
evolved recently and independently in multiple fungal lineages
Keywords:
cyanase, metabolic clustering, F. oxysporum accessory
chromosomes,
Abstract:
Fungal strains showing resistance to cyanate-based
fumigants, a widely and globally used class of fungicides, pose a
significant threat to global food security. Fungi that contain the
enzymes cyanase and carbonic anhydrase show a limited capacity to
detoxify cyanate. Here, we identify a novel putative cyanate resistance
gene cluster (CR cluster) comprised of duplicated cyanase and carbonic
anhydrase copies, trace its evolution across Ascomycetes, and examine
the evolutionary dynamics of its spread across populations of a
cosmopolitan plant pathogen. Phylogenetic analysis of the two clustered
genes reveals that the CR cluster arose independently in Cochliobolus
lunatus, Oidiodendron maius, and Fusarium oxysporum. In F. oxysporum,
genome-wide examination indicates that the CR cluster varies in copy
number across isolates. Interestingly, CR cluster copies are always
found on F. oxysporum accessory chromosomes, which are enriched in
pathogenicity genes and transfer between asexual isolates. Examination
of the phylogeny and distribution of the CR cluster in 163 F. oxysporum
isolates from a wide variety of hosts suggests a recent history of
rampant transfers between isolates. The independent evolution of the CR
gene cluster in three fungal species and its spread across F. oxysporum
both suggest that this cluster evolved in response to a selection
pressure that is likely global (i.e., a pressure that affects multiple
species and continents) and recent. We hypothesize that this selection
pressure is the recent introduction of cyanate fungicides in global
agricultural practice.
